thread.title: Outdoors notebook: Youth hunt produces bag limit
thread.title_full: Outdoors notebook: Youth hunt produces bag limit - Sports - The Buffalo News

author: Will Elliott
title: Outdoors notebook: Youth hunt produces bag limit
text:
Jack Piatkowski, 14, of Depew had a hefty harvest of ducks and geese with his guide and mentor Ryan O’Neill, pro staffer with Zink Calls and Avian-X Decoys, during the Waterfowl Youth Hunt held Oct. 3-4.
O’Neill set up at the Oak Orchard Wildlife Management Area on Saturday in chilling north winds and Piatkowski had to wait until legal shooting time to take his birds.
A good variety of mallard and wood duck decoys were presented with a few black ducks O’Neill said were “mixed in for realism.”
This setup was adequately attractive to draw in enough birds for Piatkowski to take a limit of ducks in 35 minutes – three wood ducks, two mallards and a wigeon.
On the second day, O’Neill opted to work a farm pond near Chaffee where the youth could get shots at both ducks and geese. Warmer temperatures slowed bird movement, but ducks began moving at sunrise and the geese began showing at 9 a.m. Piatkowski had his four mallards before 7:45 a.m. and O’Neill’s Zink call was able to pull a few geese from passing flights, enough for his youth to harvest a limit by 10 a.m.
A Youth Pheasant Hunt is on this weekend and a Youth Firearms Deer Hunt continues this weekend and Monday.
Walleye university
One good option for a holiday gift would be a registration in the Walleye Fishing University to be held Jan. 9 in the Grange Building on the Erie County Fairgrounds in Hamburg.
Jim and Diane Steel, with Innovative Outdoors, have a solid slate of speaker/presenters, and they are adding more ’eye experts to the day’s agenda.
An $80 registration includes a T-shirt, continental breakfast and lunch during the programs. Presentations will be in classroom settings and on-board setups. For more details and to register, call 481-5348 or visit walleyefishinguniversity.com or Innovative-Outdoors.com.
Trapping permits
Trappers can obtain permits for Oak Orchard, Tonawanda and John White Wildlife Management Areas for the 2015-16 license year by appearing in person at the Iroquois National Wildlife Refuge Office on Casey Road in Basom from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. weekdays.
To apply by mail, write to: NYSDEC, Bureau of Wildlife, 1101 Casey Road, Basom, N.Y., 14013. Open seasons at the state and federal refuge areas are set later in the species seasons. For more specifics on seasons and permits, call (585) 948-5445.
Penn Dixie openings
The Penn Dixie Paleontological & Outdoor Education Center will remain open on weekends through October and will celebrate with public-welcome openings on Columbus Day and on National Fossil Day (Wednesday).
The Penn Dixie site, ranked No. 1 among fossil parks in the United States, offers visitors views for the many varieties of fossils and the proper gear.
These open days at the Penn Dixie site will be an opportunity to say farewell to Jerold “Jerry” Bastedo, longtime executive director of the site, who will be retiring sometime near Thanksgiving.
Another chance to say goodbye to Jerry will come Nov. 5 during the Hamburg Natural History Society’s 20th annual fundraiser at LaGalleria Restaurant in Orchard Park. For details on the Penn Dixie site and the fundraiser, call 627-4560 or visit penndixie.org .
